thread.title: Festival travel vouchers given away to family of girl with brain tumor
thread.title_full: Festival travel vouchers given away to family of girl with brain tumor

author: David Burroughs
title: Festival travel vouchers given away to family of girl with brain tumor
text:
Festival travel vouchers given away to family of girl with brain tumor DAVID BURROUGHS Last updated 17:31, February 13 2017 ANDY JACKSON/Fairfax NZ 
The Morris family, Nathan, 13, Jake, 7, Paul, Nikki, Jaime, 10 months, Duggie, 5, and Tyler, 10, won a $2000 travel voucher through the Festival of Lights but decided to give it away. 
When Nikki Morris entered a competition to win a $2000 travel voucher, she hoped to use it to fly to the UK to see her brother marry her best friend. 
But after her husband Paul showed her the story of 11-year-old Taranaki girl Renee Eagar , who is flying to America later this month for potentially life-changing surgery on a brain tumour, Nikki knew she couldn't keep the tickets for herself. 
"That was it then, my heart strings were pulled and I thought how can I sit on that plane knowing that family with the little girl need to be together, I just couldn't do it," the New Plymouth woman said. 
"So we'll find another way to get to the UK." 
READ MORE: * Hawke's Bay teenager finds out she has years-old brain tumour 
Paul had entered the competition for the flights as part of the TSB Bank Festival of Lights, where visitors were encouraged to share a photo of themselves at the festival in New Plymouth. 
While the idea was to win the tickets and get to the wedding, Paul had kept an eye out for anyone who needed the travel help and came across Renee's story. 
Renee, of Toko, was given $200,000 by the Ministry of Health to cover the surgery and flights to and from America for her and a caregiver, and her family are now fundraising for them all to go over together. 
Renee's mum, Alison Eagar, said she burst into tears when she got a call from a woman at the New Plymouth District Council (NPDC) on Friday telling her about the competition and the tickets. 
She said they didn't want to take them at first as they wanted the Morris family to use them. 
"We didn't want them but she was adamant so we're very humbled by the gesture," she said. 
The voucher was the icing on the cake for the family, who were blown away by the community support helping them get to America for Renee's surgery early next month. 
"We're so lucky to live in this community and in this part of the world," she said. 
While neither family knew the other, both Alison and Nikki said they were interested in meeting before the Eagar family flew out. 
NPDC venues and events manager Ron Murray said they were humbled by the Morris's decision to give the vouchers away as it went perfectly with the festival's theme. 
"They're sharing the magic," he said. 
"We're very touched by that." - Stuff
